content.title: Charitable Giving
content.subtitle: Planning, Evaluating & Maximizing Your Impact in {{STATE_NAME}}

content.label: Essential Question
content.question:
How can you align your charitable giving with your
financial goals while ensuring your donations have
the greatest positive impact?

objectives.description: Recognize the role of charitable giving in financial planning and its personal and societal benefits
Research and assess charitable organizations for transparency, efficiency, and impact
Use the PACED decision-making model to compare and select organizations to support
Create a strategic giving plan that aligns with your values and financial circumstances

terms.definition: The active effort to promote the welfare of others through the donation of money, time, or resources
terms.example: Donating to education, healthcare, environmental causes

terms.definition: Tax-exempt nonprofit organization recognized by the IRS; donations are typically tax-deductible
terms.example: Red Cross, Habitat for Humanity, local food banks

terms.definition: Amount that reduces taxable income; charitable donations to qualified orgs can lower your tax bill
Percentage of total expenses spent on programs vs. admin/fundraising‚Äîindicates operational efficiency
Independent organizations that research and rate charities based on financial health and transparency
terms.example: Charity Navigator, GuideStar, BBB Wise Giving

terms.definition: How organizations demonstrate the real-world outcomes of their programs and initiatives
terms.example: Meals served, students tutored, trees planted

leftPanel.title: Personal Motivations
paragraphs: Values & Beliefs: Supporting causes aligned with personal principles
Gratitude: Giving back for benefits received (scholarship recipients, medical survivors)
Connection: Feeling part of a community working toward shared goals
Legacy: Creating lasting impact beyond one's lifetime

highlightBox.text: Research shows charitable giving activates the brain's reward centers‚Äîgiving literally feels good!

layoutData.title: Ways to Give
bulletPoints: Direct Cash Donations: Most common; provides immediate flexibility to charities
Appreciated Assets: Donate stocks/property; avoid capital gains tax while getting deduction
Donor-Advised Fund: "Charitable savings account"‚Äîimmediate deduction, distribute over time
Planned Giving: Include charity in will or estate plan for legacy giving
Recurring Giving: Monthly donations provide predictable funding for nonprofits
Matching Gifts: Many employers match charitable donations, doubling impact
layoutData.keyPoint: üí° The best strategy depends on your income, assets, and charitable goals. Consider consulting a financial advisor for significant giving.

leftPanel.title: Not All Charities Are Equal
paragraphs: Charitable giving is powerful, but not all organizations use donations with the same efficiency or effectiveness.
Some may allocate large portions of funds to administrative costs rather than direct programs.
Others might not be legitimate at all‚Äîcharity scams cost Americans hundreds of millions of dollars each year.

highlightBox.text: By developing research skills, you become a more informed and impactful donor.

tools.name: Charity Navigator
tools.description: Star ratings (0-4), financial health scores, accountability metrics for 200,000+ charities

tools.name: GuideStar (Candid)
tools.description: Detailed nonprofit profiles, IRS Form 990 data, transparency seals (Bronze, Silver, Gold, Platinum)

tools.name: BBB Wise Giving Alliance
tools.description: Standards-based evaluation, 20 accountability standards, "Meets Standards" seal

tools.name: GiveWell
tools.description: In-depth research on cost-effectiveness, "Top Charities" for maximum impact per dollar

tools.name: IRS Tax Exempt Search
tools.description: Verify 501(c)(3) status, check if donations are tax-deductible, official government database

tools.name: Charity Website
tools.description: Annual reports, financial statements, program descriptions, leadership bios, impact stories

infoCard.title: üìä Financial Health
items: Program Expense Ratio: % spent on programs (aim for 75%+)
Fundraising Efficiency: Cost to raise $1 (under $0.25 is good)

layoutData.bottomKeyPoint: üí° Context Matters: A 65% program ratio might be appropriate for a new or small charity building capacity. Look at trends over time, not just single-year snapshots.

layoutData.title: A Framework for Charitable Decisions

steps.title: Problem
steps.description: Define the issue you want to address

steps.title: Alternatives
steps.description: List charities working on this issue

layoutData.keyPoint: üí° Using a structured approach removes emotion from the decision and ensures you're giving to organizations that align with your values AND demonstrate effectiveness.

scenario.name: Maya: Intentional Philanthropy
paragraphs: Maya earns $60,000/year and wants to give 5% ($3,000) to causes she cares about. She's passionate about education equity.
She uses Charity Navigator and GiveWell to research organizations, creates a shortlist of 5, and uses the PACED model to evaluate them.
Maya splits her giving: $200/month to her top-rated organization, creating predictable funding they can plan around.

scenario.name: Jake: Reactive Donations
paragraphs: Jake gives impulsively whenever he sees an emotional appeal. He responds to social media campaigns, phone calls, and sidewalk solicitors.
He donates similar amounts as Maya ($3,000/year) but to 12 different organizations he hasn't researched.
Later he discovers one "charity" was actually a for-profit telemarketer keeping 85% of donations. Others had significant overlap.

items: Use watchdog sites to evaluate options

items: What issues matter most to you?
Local vs. national vs. international impact?
Direct service vs. advocacy vs. research?

layoutData.title: Other Ways to Make an Impact
bulletPoints: Volunteer Time: Skills-based volunteering often has more impact than general help
In-Kind Donations: Goods, services, or professional expertise
Advocacy: Using your voice to raise awareness or influence policy
Peer Fundraising: Organizing drives or campaigns among friends/colleagues
Board Service: Joining a nonprofit board to provide governance and expertise
Social Media: Amplifying charity messages to your network
layoutData.keyPoint: üí° For students and young adults with limited income, volunteer time and advocacy can be equally valuable as financial donations‚Äîespecially when using specialized skills.

takeaways.title: Give Strategically
takeaways.description: Charitable giving should be part of your financial plan‚Äîset a budget, choose causes intentionally, and maximize impact.

takeaways.title: Research Before You Give
takeaways.description: Use charity watchdog sites to evaluate transparency, efficiency, and impact. Not all charities are equal.

takeaways.title: Watch for Red Flags
takeaways.description: High-pressure tactics, vague fund usage, and resistance to questions are warning signs of ineffective or fraudulent charities.

takeaways.title: Impact Beyond Money
takeaways.description: Volunteering, advocacy, and skills-based contributions can be as valuable as financial donations‚Äîespecially for students.

main.title: Research & Compare
main.description: Apply your knowledge by researching and evaluating real charitable organizations using the PACED decision model. This activity will help you develop the skills to make informed, impactful giving decisions throughout your life.

steps: Choose a cause area you care about
Identify 3 charities working on this issue
Create comparison chart with key metrics
Use PACED to select and justify your choice
